{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3599972,"name":"Chris_Elston","username":"Chris_Elston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_elston/{size}/256883_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T15:17:40.898Z","cooked":"

I took some inspiration from another thread but I wanted to talk about your “Controls Strategy” on your team. I believe that this game was a “software” game. Meaning, that you needed to have good software or what I call semi-automatic features on your robot. We are curious how others solved your software with either sensors or algorithms.

The most important aspect of the game was position alignment of your robot and to be able to do that QUICKLY.

I am wondering if others would be willing to describe or discuss their controls stragety. Our primary strategy was vision using Limelight 4s and position PID with April Tags used for telemetry.

What did you use?

Our stragety started off with multi cameras, mainly Limelight 4s by looking at ALL THE April Tags to determine the telemetry of the robot. Which later we changed because the April Tag relationship was doomed with different placement and of the field element from setup to setup. In the end we changed to only looking at tags that mattered as explained below.

Of course, this assumes that you already have a TUNED swerve drive base and you can command your X,Y position of your swerve drive base to some + or - cm or inches repeatable. I believe we got down to about + or - 3 cm which is about + or - 1 inch on the drive base with just motion controls and PID tuning with SYSID.

Step 1.
That being said our primary stragety in tele-op when scoring coral was to drive the robot manually to a Reef Face where the front cameras can see the April Tag on that face.

Step 2.
The front cameras did a LOOKUP of the April Tag it saw, if the left trigger was pulled the robot loaded the X,Y of the left pipe, if the right trigger was pulled the robot loaded the X,Y of the right pipe.

Step 3.
Because the robot saw the april tag, we updated the current position of the robot and then a position based PID was executed to move the robot to where it is now, to the X,Y position of the pipe using a PID motion command of X,Y.

Step 4.
Once the tolerance of the X,Y position met the desired commanded by some “tolerance value” of say + or - 5 cm, then the robot executed the coral score sequence, AKA, run the coral score motor.

The same method was used to get coral from the load station, only we looked at the REAR camera to find the April Tag instead of the front cameras.

The problem with Step 4, was PID tuning and tolerancing sometimes made it slow for the robot to score, because the drive base was still trying to drive to the last bit of “ERROR” it saw before it was in tolerance. I am wondering if others solved this by using distance sensing or other methods to quickly score faster or end the robot command per say to move on to the next sequence.

Our Auto program was about the same except the first part was a pathplanner movement.

Step 1.
Move robot to first pipe via pathplanner movement.

Step 2.
Then a position X,Y and PID command from April Tag to April Tag to create the rest of the auto.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T15:17:40.898Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":138,"reads":962,"readers_count":961,"score":1087.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500147,"topic_slug":"let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software","display_username":"Chris_Elston","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/how-did-your-team-do-auto-alignment-this-year/503341/5","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"How did your team do auto alignment this year?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3040,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software/500147/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600088,"name":"Amicus1","username":"Amicus1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a9adbd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T16:01:52.108Z","cooked":"

Our worlds strategy was similar except we used PhotonVision with 4x reef cameras. The front cameras and back cameras looked slightly cross-eyed as you drew. We could score L3/L4 out the front and back at that point in the season, so we needed to be able to align both ways.

For coral scoring we pre-selected one of 12 branches and a level. Based on the level and the heading of the robot, it used one of three maps of branch number to pose (front facing reef, back facing reef, L1 special position).

We did use closest-side logic for algae removal though. We did this not with viewed AprilTags but by determining which direction the reef-center-to-robot vector was in, and thus which of 6 sectors.

Our pose estimation was constantly running, but was filtered to only reef tags. Future work would be to use a field map for multi-tag estimates that only includes reef tags, so that the other elements are not assumed to be correctly placed. None of our full-robot automation cared about what tags were in view or even that the pose estimation was vision-assisted. The drivetrain just supplied the estimated pose for all needed uses.

Our Step 3 and 4 looked about the same, though for auto we used Choreo paths with normally unnecessary extra auto align at the end. Our teleop align was profiled, but this is not necessary as long as the magnitude of the PID effort is clamped IMO.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T16:01:52.108Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":843,"readers_count":842,"score":193.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500147,"topic_slug":"let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software","display_username":"Amicus1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33946,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue"},"post_url":"/t/let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software/500147/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600110,"name":"Aidan","username":"FieryFuryGame","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fieryfurygame/{size}/262141_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T16:13:01.956Z","cooked":"

We attempted to use PathPlanner pathfinding and then following a path, using the tag that was visible on a Limelight 3. Depending on a bumper pressed, the robot would go to the left or right branch. This has several issues, and we didn’t have time to fix them during competition season.

Pathfinding ended up being relatively inaccurate, due to us manually creating each path, which means that some of our branch positions were likely wrong. Along with this, our Limelight position wasn’t ideal, so our driver had to position the robot to face very specifically, to avoid going to the wrong side of the reef. There were also issues if the driver was moving as they tried to pathfind, where the robot would get stuck in a somewhat random position. Our driver found it faster to align manually.

During offseason, our goal is to implement PathPlanner’s on-the-fly paths. We use tags for just Pose Estimation, and then we find the nearest branch to our position. We then generate a path to that position. This doesn’t appear to have any issues during simulation, though we might have to ensure that the robot actually finishes the path. This does seem much faster and much more accurate than the previous solution. 4915 has a very good resource on this method: 4915 PathPlanner Auto Align Whitepaper

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T17:55:03.736Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":772,"readers_count":771,"score":259.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500147,"topic_slug":"let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software","display_username":"Aidan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/4915-pathplanner-auto-align-whitepaper/494669","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"4915 PathPlanner Auto Align Whitepaper","clicks":35}],"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74068,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1262 Programming Lead"},"post_url":"/t/let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software/500147/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600131,"name":"Martin Nemaric","username":"Martini159","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T16:29:45.197Z","cooked":"

We used one Limelight in the center of the robot facing straight forward (for the reef) and another Limelight in the center of the robot facing forward and upwards (for the coral station).

Both were filtered to only look at AprilTags at their respective areas, and both were used only for global pose estimation based on MegaTag1, as we could never get MegaTag2 to work 100% of the time.

Our final approach to aligning to the reef and coral station was the same…

  1. Pathfind to a staging pose which was 2 feet behind our desired scoring / intake pose
  2. Use positional PID to do the final alignment to our true desired scoring / intake pose

We were hoping to have to only do #1, but with no characterization and feedforwards for our drivebase, #1 ended up being pretty good but not very accurate. Tacking on #2 at the very end ensured that we were exactly where we wanted to be.

Initially we had experimented with pathfinding to a (GUI-created) path which started at our staging pose, and ended at our scoring / intake pose. This was surprisingly accurate, but there was a lot of pointless decelerating and accelerating. It was also annoying to have to maintain these 12 paths in the GUI. We switched to the aforementioned method, which was a little more accurate, but also faster. Statbotics put us at 11.4 gamepieces at our first competition, and 13.5 for our second. This was without any mechanical changes.

A caveat to all of this: we only scored L1, so our alignment requirements are probably pretty fundamentally different than someone scoring L2 through L4. Our desired capture envelope left to right was multiple inches, while our capture envelope for depth (ie. into the reef) was probably around 1/2 inch when we went to stack the third piece of coral.

We feel like the main benefit to our method was that we could easily go to score or intake from literally any location on the field (to the point where our robot could function totally autonomously during teleop, as long as we updated scoring positions). This was nice when we had a clean lane and nothing on the ground blocking scoring / intaking. Of course this is rarely what an actual match is like!

The only thing we struggled with was seeing the reef tag while at the true scoring location. We could reliably see it from the staging pose, but as we got close to the reef, we would lose sight of the tag. In a perfect world, we probably would want 2 Limelights facing the reef, or make it so that our single reef Limelight could see the tag when we were at our scoring pose.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T16:29:45.197Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":725,"readers_count":724,"score":190.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500147,"topic_slug":"let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software","display_username":"Martin Nemaric","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":33946,"username":"Amicus1","name":"Amicus1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a9adbd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56673,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software/500147/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600146,"name":"Tom","username":"Tom_Neu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_neu/{size}/222407_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T16:36:47.831Z","cooked":"

We went for a simpler setup. We had 1 Limelight 3G that is in a position to see the reef tags.
We combined the position the limelight returned with our drivetrain odometry.
Our control scheme was the following, the operator selects on what level they would like to place the coral on, the driver would move the robot to the side of the reef he would like to place the coral on, and hit one of the triggers (eg, left and right) then the robot will take control and will score coral fully autonomously.
For the driving path we tried to use pathplanner, and we were not happy with the trajectories it generated, it did not account for acceleration properly and starting velocity. We created a custom on the fly path generator that accounts for all of the parameters we wanted and it was very nice.
while driving to score the coral if the robot detects a stall in the drivetrain it would change the height of the elevator and arm position to make sure we are still able to score. In our testing it worked so well we can score with a Algae between the robot and the reef.
The operator also has a button that if is pressed while trying to intake coral from the coral station the robot would extend the arm to reach the proper position.

In auto, we used our auto alignment code to score coral and use the same path generation to drive to the coral station

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T16:36:47.831Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":677,"readers_count":676,"score":185.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500147,"topic_slug":"let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59306,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5554 - Alumni. Former head of software, strategy and development"},"post_url":"/t/let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software/500147/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600182,"name":"Jared Russell","username":"Jared_Russell","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jared_russell/{size}/399_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T16:57:54.977Z","cooked":"

Our robot has to drive into the peg with the coral extended to score, which is in some ways a much more complex control challenge than “align then score” at high speeds. It took a lot of time and iteration to make it work reasonably well.

We will save the more detailed rundown for our code release, but in general we started with CTRE Swerve Drivetrain + Limelight 4 Megatag + PathPlanner on the fly paths, then modified our vision, path planning, and control stacks extensively to get the performance we needed for our robot. Several of the things we did are likely beneficial to most and will hopefully find their way back into upstream libraries in time.

The other thing that might be considered novel about our controls stack this year is that a decent portion of it (especially mathematically complex parts) was AI generated.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T17:00:52.899Z","reply_count":6,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":42,"reads":661,"readers_count":660,"score":732.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500147,"topic_slug":"let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software","display_username":"Jared Russell","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":22}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Oh so close"},"post_url":"/t/let-s-review-reefscape-s-controls-software-strategy-how-did-you-solve-position-and-accuracy-with-software/500147/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":21},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"cry","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":26,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600197,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T17:02:45.902Z","cooked":"

Our cameras moved around a lot during the season, but we ended up with a pretty simple arrangement that I didn’t see too many other teams using. They looked like this at Houston:

image1884×4080 587 KB

  1. “Front Right” Camera, with 70 deg lens, set about 6" back from the Frame Perimeter, looking forward towards the Reef. This camera was used to update the robots’ odometry every time it sees two April Tags. This constantly-updated global pose was used to generate on-the-fly paths between the robots’ current location (and speed) to the selected reef pole or HP station, finishing about 4" away, and at about 0.5 m/s. At our first event, our drivers did all of the pathing and alignment manually and were able to max out at about 14 cycles per match (2 in auto, 8-12 in teleop plus a climb).
    Camera 1 helped us bump that to ~16 cycles per match at our second and third events (2 in auto, 12-14 in teleop), with about ~20% dropped.

  2. “Front Left” Camera, with 105 deg “fisheye” lens, centered under the Coral Ejector. This was used once the robot was within ~1m of the Reef to make a final odometry correction before centering the Ejector at the target Reef pole. The wider lens was sufficient to see keep the tag recognition valid even when the robot was +/- about 8" misaligned. The “trust” correction we apply to the single-tag estimate is set very high, and increases with decreasing distance to the reef.
    Camera 2 helped us get to 17-20 cycles per match at Houston by almost eliminating our Coral drops. That (finally) met our kickoff performance goal, and put us in the top ~50 worldwide EPA. 17 teleop cycles is also probably close to the limit for our architecture, since during our shortest cycles the Coral is only just finishing the handoff between funnel and Ejector.

The tech stack was as follows:

  • Both cameras were Arducam’s, controlled and analyzed by a single Orange Pi 5 connected to the Rio via Ethernet through a network switch.
  • The global pose was calculated using Photonvision’s multi tag (camera 1) and single tag (camera 2) solvers running on the Pi. In the single tag mode (camera 2), we get the robot’s angle from the gyro (CTRE Pigeon) instead of the tag.
  • The camera-estimated global pose was fused with odometry using WPILib’s SwervePoseEstimator
  • The on-the-fly paths were generated and followed by Pathplanner. We use an additional PID at the end of the path to drive us to the path end point.
  • 6328’s AdvantageScope app was absolutely indispensable for monitoring and debugging this crazy (for us) scheme.

I am not on the programming team, but I can direct any questions to them. Eventually our code will be shared on github.

High level overview as I wasn’t intimately involved in the coding portion:

  • 4 cameras (2 forward, 2 rear facing) looking for the apriltags on the reef - our odometry had too much noise when looking for the coral stations, processor, and barge tags.
  • Our operator had a 4x6 keyboard pad where they would select the branch and level to score on (or the level and reef face to remove an algae from). You could select this at any time as it was just a queue action
  • Our end effector had a CANRange sensor on one end to give an additional offset to where the coral was vertically placed in the end effector
  • All of our driver commands were press+hold commands. Releasing the button would cause the robot to stop its current command, return to the stow position, and wait for further instructions. A single trigger hold would execute an auto-align to the queued position from the operator console.
  • Auto-align would work from anywhere on the field, building an on the fly path generation through choreo, moving to a position about 2 feet in front of the reef face that you wanted, then would drive forward to align itself about 5 inches from the reef face with the coral lined up over the branch.
  • A level 1/2/3 auto align would score automatically as soon as the robot was happy it was within happy thresholds, while L4 coral would wait for the driver to signal they were happy with the alignment.
  • Processor scoring would face the robot toward the processor so the driver only had to align distance, not direction.
  • Intake would align the robot towards the nearest coral station (if you were in intake and drove across the middle driver station it would flip around to face the now nearest coral station). Two intake levels were defined, one for directly against the coral station, one for if there was a coral up against the station.

For practical purposes it was slightly faster and safer for our driver to drive until they were a few feet from the reef and then auto align in from there. The odometry system would give small rumbles on the driver controller when it was getting good apriltag readings so they could always be confident when they started to auto-align.

If you watch our matches you may be able to see our LEDS change with queued positions and then when auto-aligning, including being blinded by bright yellow when we called for L1 intakes from human players. These LEDs were used by our human player somewhat, but were mostly used in the end for being pretty and quick debugging from match video before looking into robot logs.

TLDR: Choreo dynamic pathing combined with a CANrange sensor allowed us to align from anywhere on the field to any branch level on the reef with an offset of up to 12 inches based on where coral was in our intake.

We generally used AI for writing self-contained utility methods for vision, geometry, or planning as opposed to trying to solve integration into the codebase for us. This both makes it easier to prompt the AI with sufficient context, and makes it easier for us to verify that the outputs are correct.

We also used AI extensively for other things, like summarizing scouting data. Or generating internal memes.

My apologies, like I said [my understanding is] super high level. Looks instead like our auto paths were done through Choreo and anything dynamic was done through a package we called wayfinder. It has this comment on it:

Swerve setpoint generator that has been passed around so many times its hard to keep track, just know i didn't write most the logic in this code that credit goes to 254 and mjansen.
 Takes a prior setpoint, a desired setpoint, and outputs a new setpoint that respects all the kinematic constraints on module rotation and wheel velocity/torque, as well as preventing any forces acting on a module's wheel from exceeding the force of friction.

Chris_Elston:

What did you use?

We used our (4915) on-the-fly pathing setup during the build & comp season!

I talked around during the competitions and made a short list of several other methods from other teams:

  • Profiled pid controller
  • Adaptive pure pursuit controller
  • A* pathfinding using pathplanner
  • A* pathfinding which then get smoothed out using Bezier splines!
  • x, y, & theta pid controller

Max_Morehead:

Were the pre-generated paths from choreo or was the point just to save some processing time.

The pre-generated paths were also generated “on the fly”, but this happened while the robot meditated pre-match, and they populated the path cache so that we would get cheap cache hits in auto in the nominal case (that we didn’t need to cancel a path early due to some issue). If we had to abort a path too early we’d re-generate them from scratch.

Wayfinder is just a package i made to include various custom and borrowed drivetrain control technologies. The one the mentor commented on here is like pathplanners setpoint generator but i optimized it to make no new objects at runtime. The “dynamic trajectory generation” is an implementation of repulsor field. Repulsor field is like a vector map/gradient map that was being talked about in discords before the season started. I copied the initial implementation from children of the corn but built upon it heavily. My implementation allows swapping between repulsor fields on the fly and passing in custom controllers. I can go more in depth but we will have an official code release soon with documentation.
